functionalRequirements.impact: Optimize space utilization, reduce energy consumption and operating costs, and improve employee productivity and satisfaction.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainable Sourcing & Procurement
logicalComponents.description: Sustainable sourcing and procurement refers to the processes and practices used to acquire goods and services in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

functionalRequirements.name: ESG Goal setting and tracking
functionalRequirements.description: ESG Goal setting and tracking function help organizations to identify areas where they can improve sustainability performance, track progress toward their sustainability goals, and report on their achievements to stakeholders, investors, and regulators.
functionalRequirements.impact: It enables organizations to improve their sustainability performance, align with stakeholder expectations, and achieve long-term business success through sustainable practices.

logicalComponents.name: Sustainable Space
logicalComponents.description: Sustainable space refers to physical spaces, such as buildings, neighborhoods, or communities, that are designed and operated in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

overview.content:
Asset Life Cycle Management
An asset is defined as something useful or valuable to an organization. The term includes physical and non-physical assets such as infrastructure, equipment, capital, and people. The asset lifecycle refers to the end-to-end process by which an asset is purchased, stored, used, and maintained throughout its useful life by its owner.

Organizations track the health of their assets by using several methods. Many use data from sensors connected to theÂ Internet of Things (IoT)Â to monitor asset health real-time performance and performÂ preventive maintenanceÂ when necessary.

As part of an overall maintenance strategy, asset maintenance is performed regularly to reduce maintenance costs, extend asset life, and avoid unplanned downtime.

IBM Asset Lifecycle Management â Integrated Solution

Asset Lifecycle Management Reference Architecture
The Asset Life Cycle Management reference architecture diagram demonstrates how integrated software applications across business functions can support organizations in achieving their Sustainability objectives. It provides a holistic view of data sources capturing critical sustainability metrics and shows how they are collected, assembled, analyzed, and reported to facilitate comprehensive corporate sustainability reporting. This process is essential for aligning organizational operations with sustainability goals.

The diagram also emphasizes the role of these data sources in actively operationalizing sustainability initiatives, from tracking to reporting to executing corrective actions through AI-powered applications. Organizations can minimize environmental impacts, enhance asset performance, and uphold regulatory compliance by managing the entire asset lifecycleâfrom planning and deployment to optimization and disposal. The image below visually represents the sustainability operations journey.



To achieve sustainable operations, companies need to embark on a journey that starts with a strategy and roadmap. A sustainability strategy and roadmap set the stage for managing assets to balance environmental, social, and economic goals, making it easier to implement Asset Life Cycle Management in a business.

The next step in the process is ESG and data reporting, which are essential in Asset Life Cycle Management because they enable organizations to track, analyze, and optimize asset performance in alignment with sustainability goals, ensuring compliance, enhancing operational efficiency and minimizing environmental impact.

The journey will vary depending on the customer's current state, priorities, and goals. For example, the next step in the above journey map is intelligent asset and facility infrastructure, where IBM Maximo and TRIRIGA applications can help reduce scope 1 and 2 emissions.

Climate Risk Management is a crucial final step in Asset Life Cycle Management as it helps organizations assess and mitigate climate-related risks, ensuring asset resilience, reducing potential financial losses, and supporting long-term sustainability.

By following the above stepsâdeveloping a sustainability strategy and roadmap, implementing ESG data reporting, leveraging intelligent assets and infrastructure, and managing climate risksâ customers can effectively achieve their asset life cycle management goals and create a more sustainable and resilient enterprise.

No matter what options customers choose, IBM has a solution that can help them achieve their sustainability goals. You can refer to the following external links to learn about IBM's sustainability offerings in these areas.

  1. Sustainability Strategy and Roadmap
  2. ESG Data and Reporting
  3. Intelligent assets & facilities infrastructure
  4. Climate Risk Management

Here, we are focused on Asset Life Cycle Management Reference architecture. For an overview of it, see section 5.1.2. It covers various systems within an enterprise essential for capturing, reporting, and operationalizing sustainability goals. We are developing a drilled-down version of the Asset Life Cycle Management Architecture; you will find those in the following list. We will update these links to include additional architectures as and when it is available.

  1. ESG Data Reporting Reference Architecture
  2. Intelligent Asset Reference Architecture
  3. Intelligent Facility Reference Architecture
  4. Climate Risk Management Reference Architecture

If you have any questions or comments, contact SSW-Architecture-Questions@ibm.com

businessChallenge.content:
Business Challenge: Achieving Carbon Emission Reduction Goals

Many businesses face the challenge of achieving rigorous carbon emission reduction goals to meet the demands of various stakeholders, regulators, and peers. However, they often struggle to achieve these goals using silo systems that do not share data, are difficult to integrate, and are expensive to operate. This lack of integration and data sharing makes it hard for businesses to track their progress and hinders their ability to achieve their carbon reduction targets. To address this challenge, businesses need a simple, user-friendly software solution to help operationalize their ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) goals, streamline their efforts to reduce emissions, and provide real-time visibility into their progress toward meeting their reduction targets.

nonFunctionalRequirements.value: Mitigate risks, protect sensitive information, and maintain stakeholders' trust, ensuring systems' reliability and resilience in the face of potential threats and vulnerabilities.

nonFunctionalRequirements.description: It is the degree to which a system or application is user-friendly and intuitive, enabling efficient and effective user interactions while minimizing the learning curve and user errors.
nonFunctionalRequirements.context: The design and interface considerations optimize user experiences, ensuring that digital systems and applications are intuitive, accessible, and efficient for their intended users.
nonFunctionalRequirements.value: Enhance user satisfaction, productivity, and adoption rates, ultimately leading to more effective and user-friendly systems that meet the needs and expectations of their users.

nonFunctionalRequirements.name: High Availablity & Disaster Recovery
nonFunctionalRequirements.description: High Availability means a system can remain operational and accessible for extended periods, minimizing downtime and ensuring continuous service availability. Disaster Recovery focuses on the strategies and processes to swiftly recover and restore IT systems and data in a catastrophic failure or disaster.
nonFunctionalRequirements.context: High Availability pertains to maintaining uninterrupted system operation, whereas "Disaster Recovery" addresses the processes and measures necessary for swiftly restoring functionality after a significant system failure or catastrophic event.
nonFunctionalRequirements.value: It ensures business continuity, minimizes downtime, and safeguards against data loss, enhancing system reliability and resilience to disruptions.

fromElement.description: Application users refer to individuals with different roles and responsibilities within an enterprise, such as Sustainability Managers, Operations and Maintenance Managers, Supply Chain and Procurement Managers, Risk and Finance Managers, and IT and Sustainability Managers, who use an application for managing ESG reporting, assets and facilities, supply chain, climate risk, and IT sustainability infrastructure.

aodEnterprise.name: Enterprise View ALM 1.0
aodEnterprise.description: A comprehensive framework that outlines best practices, guidelines, and principles for designing and implementing sustainable IT and business processes, fostering environmental and social responsibility within an organization.

subSystems.name: Asset & Facilities Management
subSystems.description: The asset and facilities management layer allows customers to enable sustainability centric planning, operation, and management of their complex physical assets and facilities.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Efficiency Finder
containedLogicalComponents.description: Application to identify and analyze the efficiency of assets within an asset management system. This may include identifying opportunities for improving the performance or efficiency of the asset, as well as identifying potential problems or inefficiencies that could impact its performance.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Green Leases
containedLogicalComponents.description: Green leases are leases for commercial or residential properties that include provisions related to environmental sustainability and energy efficiency. These provisions may require the tenant or property owner to take certain actions to reduce their environmental impact, such as using energy-efficient appliances or implementing water conservation measures.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Intelligent Maintenance
containedLogicalComponents.description: Application for managing and maintaining assets that use data and analytics to predict when maintenance is needed. This approach is designed to optimize the maintenance schedule for an asset based on its actual condition, rather than following a predetermined schedule or reacting to failures.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainable Health
containedLogicalComponents.description: It is the ability of an asset to operate effectively and efficiently over a long period of time without incurring excessive costs or causing negative impacts on the environment.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainable Projects
containedLogicalComponents.description: Sustainable projects aim to reduce environmental impacts, such as greenhouse gas emissions or resource consumption, or improve social and economic conditions by creating jobs or improving quality of life.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainable Space
containedLogicalComponents.description: Sustainable space refers to physical spaces, such as buildings, neighborhoods, or communities, that are designed and operated in a way that is environmentally, socially, and economically responsible and sustainable over the long term.

subSystems.name: Climate Risk
subSystems.description: The climate risk layer allows customers to identify, track, manage and mitigate climate-based risks [for example - temperature, humidity, precipitation, frost etc.]

containedLogicalComponents.name: Climate Risk Map
containedLogicalComponents.description: A climate risk map is a visual representation of the potential risks and impacts of climate change on a particular region or area.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Environmental Data
containedLogicalComponents.description: Environmental data refers to information that is collected about the natural environment and its various components, such as air, water, soil, plants, etc. This data can be collected using various methods, including field observations, remote sensing, and laboratory analysis, and it can be used to understand and monitor the health and functioning of the environment.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Geospatial Analytics
containedLogicalComponents.description: Geospatial analytics is the analysis of spatial data to understand and visualize patterns, trends, and relationships in a geographic context.

subSystems.name: Integration
subSystems.description: The integration layer is the first stage in consuming information from the physical layer and will provide the interface to data and/or functionality of one or more sustainability applications.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Connector
containedLogicalComponents.description: Connector refers to a device or software that allows different devices or systems to communicate and exchange data with each other. Connectors enable the interoperability of different devices and systems, allowing them to work together and share data over a network.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Edge
containedLogicalComponents.description: The "edge devices" are responsible for collecting, processing, and transmitting data from the assets being monitored, often in real-time.

containedLogicalComponents.name: EDI
containedLogicalComponents.description: Electronic Data Exchange (EDI) enables secure, automated transfer of standardized data between systems, streamlining communication and integration across organizations.

containedLogicalComponents.name: External Events
containedLogicalComponents.description: External events refer to changes in the environment or external conditions that can impact the operation of systems. External events can include a wide range of factors, such as temperature, humidity, air quality, or other physical conditions; certain substances or materials; or the presence or movement of people or objects.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Financials
containedLogicalComponents.description: Financial include various metrics, such as revenue, profits, expenses, cash flow, assets, liabilities, and equity.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Locations
containedLogicalComponents.description: Location refers to the physical location of devices, sensors, and other assets connected to the network.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Protocol Adapters
containedLogicalComponents.description: A protocol adapter is a tool connecting two different types of data so that they can work together as you want.

containedLogicalComponents.name: REST API
containedLogicalComponents.description: REST API (short for Representational State Transfer Application Programming Interface) is a type of API that allows software applications to communicate with each other over the internet. REST APIs use a standard set of protocols and data formats to exchange information between applications, allowing them to communicate and share data in a consistent and predictable manner.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Web forms
containedLogicalComponents.description: A web form is a user interface element on a website that allows users to input and submit data to the website.

subSystems.name: Physical
subSystems.description: The physical layer is the foundation system of the Sustainability architecture where the data gets generated and stored.

containedActors.name: Metering System

containedActors.name: Network Equipment
containedActors.description: Network equipment refers to the hardware and software that is used to connect devices and systems to a network, such as a local area network (LAN) or a wide area network (WAN). Network equipment includes devices such as routers, switches, hubs, and modems, as well as cables and other connectivity devices.

containedActors.name: Sensors

containedActors.name: Spreadsheets
containedActors.description: A physical layer spreadsheet contains transactional and interval data of asset assets in the facility.

subSystems.name: AI & Analytics
subSystems.description: The AI & Analytics layer allows customers to sift through their sustainability application data points and extract valuable insights.

containedLogicalComponents.name: AI Assistant
containedLogicalComponents.description: An AI assistant is a software application or system that is designed to perform tasks and provide assistance to users using artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, such as natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Computer Vision
containedLogicalComponents.description: Computer vision is a field of artificial intelligence (AI) that involves the development of algorithms and systems that can interpret and understand visual data, such as images and videos.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Large Language Model
containedLogicalComponents.description: Prediction refers to the process of using data and algorithms to identify patterns and trends and to make forecasts or predictions about future outcomes.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Machine Learning
containedLogicalComponents.description: Machine learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence (AI) that involves the development of algorithms and models that can learn from and make predictions or decisions based on data.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Pattern Detection
containedLogicalComponents.description:
Pattern detection rules are a set of guidelines or criteria that are used to identify and classify patterns in data. 
Example - Anomaly detection

containedLogicalComponents.name: Prediction
containedLogicalComponents.description: Prediction refers to the process of using data and algorithms to identify patterns and trends and to make forecasts or predictions about future outcomes.

subSystems.name: Data Mapping and Storage
subSystems.description: The data layer will help to store, standardize and normalize data in a meaningful[example - relationship between data] way that sustainability applications can consume.

containedLogicalComponents.name: AI Broker
containedLogicalComponents.description: The AI broker is the integration hub that facilitates communication betweenÂ Application and IBM watsonx AI systems or services.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Canonical Model
containedLogicalComponents.description: Canonical Data Models are a type of data model that aim to present data entities and relationships in the simplest possible form to integrate processes across various systems.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Data Model
containedLogicalComponents.description: A data model is a way of organizing and representing data in a computer system. It defines the structure and relationships between different data pieces and serves as a blueprint for how the data will be stored and accessed.

containedLogicalComponents.name: ERP
containedLogicalComponents.description: Enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems are software platforms that are designed to help organizations manage and integrate their business processes, such as finance, accounting, human resources, procurement, and supply chain management.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Model Catalog
containedLogicalComponents.description: The model catalog is a collection of models that are used to represent and analyze different aspects of the system. A model is a simplified representation of a system or process that helps to understand and analyze it.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Processing Rules
containedLogicalComponents.description: Processing rules in data systems refer to the set of instructions or algorithms that are used to manipulate and process data within the system. These rules can be used to perform a wide range of tasks, including data validation, transformation, aggregation, and analysis.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Storage
containedLogicalComponents.description: Storage refers to the physical or virtual space where data is saved and stored for later use. Storage is an essential part of any data system, enabling it to retain and access data over time.

subSystems.name: ESG Framework
subSystems.description: The ESG Reporting Framework lets customers establish goals, and report on those goals to meet regulatory requirements including auditability. Also, it allows customers to get insights into where organizations can make changes to improve their sustainability posture.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Advancing Net Zero
containedLogicalComponents.description: Advancing Net Zero is WorldGBC's global program working towards total sector decarbonization by 2050

containedLogicalComponents.name: CDP
containedLogicalComponents.description: CDP is a not-for-profit charity that runs the global disclosure system for investors, companies, cities, states and regions to manage their environmental impacts.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Dow Jones Sustainability Index
containedLogicalComponents.description: The Dow Jones Sustainability Index was a stock index focused on European companies with high environmental, social, and governance (ESG) scores.

containedLogicalComponents.name: GHG Protocol
containedLogicalComponents.description: GHG Protocol establishes comprehensive global standardized frameworks to measure and manage greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from private and public sector operations, value chains and mitigation actions.

containedLogicalComponents.name: NPi
containedLogicalComponents.description: The Australian National Pollutant Inventory (NPI) is a database maintained by the Australian government that provides information on emissions and pollutants released into the air, water, and land by industrial facilities across Australia.

containedLogicalComponents.name: RE 100
containedLogicalComponents.description: RE100 is the global corporate renewable energy initiative bringing together hundreds of large and ambitious businesses committed to 100% renewable electricity.

containedLogicalComponents.name: SASB
containedLogicalComponents.description: SASB Standards guide the disclosure of financially material sustainability information by companies to their investors.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Science Based Targets
containedLogicalComponents.description: The Science Based Targets initiative is a collaboration between the CDP, the United Nations Global Compact, World Resources Institute and the World Wide Fund for Nature. Since 2015 more than 1,000 companies have joined the initiative to set a science-based climate target

containedLogicalComponents.name: TCFD
containedLogicalComponents.description: TCFD reporting refers to the practice of reporting on climate-related financial risks and opportunities in accordance with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (

subSystems.name: ESG Reporting
subSystems.description: The ESG platform layer allows customers to get deep visibility into environmental, human, and governance risks.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Accelerate Decarbonization
containedLogicalComponents.description: Accelerate decarbonization refers to the process of increasing the speed and scale at which carbon dioxide (CO2) and other greenhouse gases are reduced or eliminated in order to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

containedLogicalComponents.name: ESG Reporting Frameworks
containedLogicalComponents.description: ESG (environmental, social, and governance) reporting frameworks are guidelines or standards that organizations can use to report on their environmental, social, and governance performance, risks, and impacts.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Scope 1, 2 GHG Accounting + Reporting
containedLogicalComponents.description: Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) emissions are categories used to classify and report the greenhouse gas emissions of an organization. Scope 1 emissions are direct emissions that are under the control of an organization, such as emissions from company-owned vehicles or equipment. Scope 2 emissions are indirect emissions that result from an organization's consumption of purchased electricity, steam, heating, or cooling.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Scope 3 GHG Accounting + Reporting
containedLogicalComponents.description: Scope 3 GHG (greenhouse gas) accounting and reporting refers to the measurement, accounting, and reporting of greenhouse gas emissions from sources that are not directly owned or controlled by an organization, but that are related to its activities.

containedLogicalComponents.name: Sustainability Program Tracking
containedLogicalComponents.description: Sustainability program tracking is the process of monitoring and measuring the progress and performance of a sustainability program or initiative.

usageScenario.name: Managing an Asset
usageScenario.description: Managing an asset involves using an integrated platform to track, monitor, and optimize the performance, maintenance, and lifecycle of physical assets, ensuring operational efficiency and minimizing downtime.

usageSteps.description: The integration allows seamless data transfer from physical and ERP systems within the client network to enterprise sustainabilityÂ applications in hybrid cloud.
The data from physical and ERP systems are stored, analyzed, and consumed to achieve the ESG goals of an organization, therebyÂ improving its environmental sustainability performance.
Intelligent maintenance application consumes the asset data to identify operational issues, improve maintenance and reduceÂ environmental impact.
The information from asset management applications will be consumed by the ESG reporting engine for goal setting and trackingÂ the ESG goals.

usageScenario.name: Monitoring an Asset
usageScenario.description: Monitoring an asset enables real-time tracking of asset health, performance, and condition, allowing for proactive maintenance and swift issue resolution to ensure optimal operation and longevity.

usageSteps.description: The integration allows seamless data transfer from physical and ERP systems within the client network to enterprise sustainabilityÂ applications in hybrid cloud.

usageScenario.name: Optimize an Asset with AI
usageScenario.description: Optimizing an asset with AI enhances asset management by automating the classification of work orders, predicting failures, and recommending maintenance actions, leading to more efficient operations and reduced manual intervention.

properties.name: Asset operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
properties.description: Asset operations anomaly detection with actionable insight is a use case in which organizations implement advanced analytics tools to identify unusual behavior in asset performance and take corrective actions. These capabilities help improve asset efficiency, reduce downtime, and minimize the negative impact of asset operations on the environment.

properties.impact: Reduce the negative impact on their operations and enhancing their overall sustainability performance.
properties.name: Climate risk mitigation recommendation with actionable insight
properties.description: Provides actionable insights and recommendations to mitigate climate risks and improve sustainability performance for an organization.

properties.impact: Optimize space utilization, reduce energy consumption and operating costs, and improve employee productivity and satisfaction.
properties.name: Facility Space operations anomaly detection with actionable insight
properties.description: Function provides real-time monitoring and analytics to identify anomalies in facility space usage and provide actionable insights to optimize occupancy and improve space efficiency.
It is the measures and protocols implemented to safeguard data, systems, and resources from unauthorized access, breaches, and threats, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
properties.context: It is the practices, policies, and technologies implemented to safeguard digital assets, data, and operations from unauthorized access, cyberattacks, and potential breaches.
properties.name: Security
properties.value: Mitigate risks, protect sensitive information, and maintain stakeholders' trust, ensuring systems' reliability and resilience in the face of potential threats and vulnerabilities.

properties.description: It is the degree to which a system or application is user-friendly and intuitive, enabling efficient and effective user interactions while minimizing the learning curve and user errors.
properties.context: The design and interface considerations optimize user experiences, ensuring that digital systems and applications are intuitive, accessible, and efficient for their intended users.
properties.name: Usability
properties.value: Enhance user satisfaction, productivity, and adoption rates, ultimately leading to more effective and user-friendly systems that meet the needs and expectations of their users.

properties.description: It is the system's capacity to efficiently handle increased workloads and growing demands by adapting and expanding its resources without compromising performance.
properties.context: The system can seamlessly accommodate higher usage, data, or traffic levels while maintaining optimal performance and responsiveness.
properties.name: Scalability
properties.value: Capacity to support business growth and adapt to changing needs, ensuring that systems can efficiently handle increased workloads while minimizing disruptions and resource constraints.

properties.description: Different systems, technologies, and data formats can seamlessly work together and exchange information.
properties.context: Interoperability ensures that various software applications, hardware devices, and systems can exchange data and function cohesively within an architecture framework.
properties.name: Interoperability
properties.value: Facilitate seamless integration and communication between components

properties.description: Performance is the system's ability to efficiently and effectively execute tasks, processes, or functions within acceptable response times and resource utilization.
properties.context: System's ability to meet specified speed, responsiveness, and throughput expectations, ensuring optimal user experiences and efficient resource utilization.
properties.name: Performance
properties.value: Enhance user satisfaction improve operational efficiency, and overall system effectiveness by ensuring that applications and processes run swiftly and efficiently.

properties.description: High Availability means a system can remain operational and accessible for extended periods, minimizing downtime and ensuring continuous service availability. Disaster Recovery focuses on the strategies and processes to swiftly recover and restore IT systems and data in a catastrophic failure or disaster.
properties.context: High Availability pertains to maintaining uninterrupted system operation, whereas "Disaster Recovery" addresses the processes and measures necessary for swiftly restoring functionality after a significant system failure or catastrophic event.
properties.name: High Availablity & Disaster Recovery
properties.value: It ensures business continuity, minimizes downtime, and safeguards against data loss, enhancing system reliability and resilience to disruptions.

properties.name: Managing an Asset
properties.description: Managing an asset involves using an integrated platform to track, monitor, and optimize the performance, maintenance, and lifecycle of physical assets, ensuring operational efficiency and minimizing downtime.

properties.name: Monitoring an Asset
properties.description: Monitoring an asset enables real-time tracking of asset health, performance, and condition, allowing for proactive maintenance and swift issue resolution to ensure optimal operation and longevity.

properties.name: Optimize an Asset with AI
properties.description: Optimizing an asset with AI enhances asset management by automating the classification of work orders, predicting failures, and recommending maintenance actions, leading to more efficient operations and reduced manual intervention.
